The basic empty mass of an aircraft includes...
choice1: The total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding unusable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage.
choice2: The total mass of an aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation including the required fuel and crew, but excluding traffic load.
choice3: The mass of the aeroplane plus standard items such as unusable fuel and other unusable liquids, lubricating oil in engine and auxiliary units, fire extinguishers, pyrotechnics, emergency oxygen equipment, supplementary electronic equipment.
choice4: The total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation including crew, navigation instruments and engine cowling.

The term center of gravity is defined as...
choice1: The heaviest point on an aeroplane.
choice2: Half the distance between the neutral point and the datum line.
choice3: Another designation for the neutral point
choice4: The point at which the total mass of the aeroplane is considered to act.

question: The center of gravity (CG) defines...
choice1: The point on the longitudinal axis or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
choice2: The point through which the force of gravity is said to act on a mass.
choice3: The distance from the datum to the position of a mass.
choice4: The product of mass and balance arm.

question: During an unaccelerated flight...
choice1: Drag equals lift and thrust equals gravity.
choice2: Thrust equals the sum of drag and gravity.
choice3: Thrust equals lift and drag equals gravity.
choice4: Thrust equals drag and lift equals gravity.

question: The term datum with regard to a mass and balance calculation defines...
choice1: The point on the lateral axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
choice2: The point on the vertical axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
choice3: The point on the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
choice4: The distance from the reference plane to the center of gravity of an aircraft.

question: The term moment with regard to a mass and balance calculation is referred to as...
choice1: Sum of a mass and a balance arm.
choice2: Quotient of a mass and a balance arm.
choice3: Difference of a mass and a balance arm
choice4: Product of a mass and a balance arm.

question: The term balance arm in the context of a mass and balance calculation defines the...
choice1: Distance from the datum to the center of gravity of a mass.
choice2: Distance of a mass from the center of gravity.
choice3: Point on the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
choice4: Point through which the force of gravity is said to act on a mass.

question: The distance between the center of gravity and the datum is called...

choice1: The front C.G. limit and the datum line
choice2: The C.G. of a mass and the rear C.G. limit
choice3: The C.G. of a mass and the datum line
choice4: The front C.G. limit and the rear C.G. limit

How does aircraft flap configuration influence the take-off performance?
choice1: A higher flap setting decreases ground roll and increases lift-off speed and climb performance

question: How does wind affect the take-off performance?
choice1: Tailwind aids the aircraft in overcoming the initial drag at the commencement of the take-off roll. The take-off distance will decrease
choice2: Tailwind reduces the relative wind on the airfoil. The take-off distance will increase
choice3: Headwind causes an increased airflow around the wing. The take-off distance will increase
choice4: Headwind imposes an increased drag on the aircraft. The take-off distance will increase

question: It is possible that the surface wind speed at an airport is reduced due to friction. When a surface area with a minor tailwind condition is left during the initial climb, the pilot might expect.

choice4: A decrease in airspeed and rate of climb due to increasing tailwind.

question: The term steady flight is defined as...
choice1: Flight with a steady power setting without changing course
choice2: Climb or descent with a constant climb or descent rate in calm weather conditions.
choice3: Unaccelerated flight. The four forces thrust, drag, lift, and weight are in equilibrium.
choice4: Flight in smooth air without turbulence and a perfectly trimmed aircraft.
